pButton.Name: SECULARISM
pButton.popInfo: Secularism became dominant, encouraging people to be less concerned with the afterlife and to focus instead on the present and the worldly rewards of life on Earth.

pButton.Name: URBAN GROWTH
pButton.popInfo: Merchants in the Italian city states had made fortunes in commerce dominating trade routes between Europe and the Mid-East. This marks the growth of a large powerful urban, middle class who rejoiced in beautiful things that their money could buy.

pButton.Name: PATRONAGE
pButton.popInfo: With large sums of available cash, wealthy citizens became patrons of art.

pButton.Name: ARTISTS
pButton.popInfo: Artists were no longer craftsmen who followed long established rules in the creation of religious paintings and sculptures, but became innovators. While religious themes remained popular, there was a new emphasis on the human form, pagan or mythological gods and stories, peasant scenes, portraits, and landscapes.

pButton.Name: LITERATURE
pButton.popInfo: Literature was no longer only about saints and morality tales, written in Latin but became stories and poems about all aspects of mankind, written in the vernacular, or commonly spoken language.

pButton.Name: ARCHITECTURE
pButton.popInfo: Gothic cathedrals were replaced by smaller, human-scaled churches which redefined God’s relationship with man.
